column1: Liberals vs Conservatives The War Room
column30: We really need to be more vigilant in who we watch, read and share online. People are using flat earth, Covid, election fraud, vaccines and other conspiracies to make a lot of money. They know what they're peddling is truly fake and dangerous but don't care. Sadly, conspiracies spread faster than the verifiable truth. By the time the truth catches up, the damage has been done. ''...conspiracy theories, and the people who promote them, can get a lot of viewsâ€”and money. Health misinformation poses its own challenges, and existing conspiracy theories and false claims are adapting and spreading in the current pandemic faster than fact-checkingâ€”or sometimes scienceâ€”can catch up. The spread of hateful misinformation targeting marginalized groups leads to harassment, threats, and violence. Health misinformation can lead people to ignore life-saving public health measures or inspire them to try dangerous â€œcures.â€ Anthony Fauci, who along with Bill Gates has become a leading villain for coronavirus conspiracy theorists, has increased his personal security after a swell of death threats. The relationship between fringe and mainstream YouTubers can be symbiotic, according to Alice Marwick, an assistant professor in communication at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. â€œBoth members of the discussion are trying to benefit,â€ she says. â€œThe fringe person from getting this mainstream, and the mainstream from getting a potentially increased audience.â€ Anti-vaccine activists, along with other supporters of conspiracy theories, are strongly motivated to seek out bigger and bigger audiences, says Marwick. YouTube and influencer culture has long been vulnerable to their efforts, leading unwitting or unprepared personalities with large followings to host proponents of increasingly extreme views in the name of intellectual debate, curiosity, or controversy. Even when interviewers frame the video as a debate, Marwick says, â€œtheyâ€™re just opening the Overton window to whatever fringe idea is being promoted by the guest.â€ The most popular of these additions to Bet-Davidâ€™s YouTube channel, â€œDr Buttar Accuses Fauci, Gates & The Media For Using COVID-19 To Drive Hidden Agenda,â€ is a two-hour interview with Rashid Buttar, an anti-vaccine activist with his own small channel who has, among other things, claimed that the coronavirus is a bioweapon. In the video, Buttar asserts to Bet-David that the death count for covid-19 is being artificially inflated, that doctors and nurses speaking to the media are â€œpaid actors,â€ that dead bodies seen on TV and in the news are â€œmannequins,â€ and that covid-19 is no different from the â€œregular flu.â€ He also urges viewers to â€œgo out and demonstrateâ€ that the pandemic is a hoax. These statements appear to be against YouTubeâ€™s rules, but the benefit for Buttar is clear: according to SocialBlade, a third-party analytics site for influencers, he had 4,200 subscribers on March 28. He just passed 250,000. In fact, many claims by conspiracy theorists are already discredited, DiResta notes. Anti-vaccine videos are â€œa mix of jargony pseudoscience woo that's often already been debunked and huge big numbers designed to scare people, taken entirely out of context,â€ she says. â€œAudiences who aren't immersed in the facts, and are unfamiliar with anti-vaccine rhetorical games, think they're hearing something scandalous. And then they go on to tell their friends about it, or occasionally begin to follow the anti-vax influencer. â€œ I asked Bet-David whether he felt any responsibility over airing these views on his channelâ€”particularly potentially harmful claims by his guests, urging viewers to ignore public health recommendations. â€œI do not,â€ he said. â€œI am responsible for what comes out of my mouth. Iâ€™m not responsible for what comes out of your mouthâ€ For him, that lack of responsibility extends to misinformation that could be harmful to his audience. He is just giving people what they are asking for. That, in turn, drives attention, which allows him to make money from ads, merchandise, speaking gigs, and workshops. â€œItâ€™s up to the audience to make the decision for themselves,â€ he says. Besides, he thinks heâ€™s done interviewing anti-vaccine activists for now. Heâ€™s trying to book some â€œbig nameâ€ interviews of what he termed â€œpro-vaccineâ€ experts. But the anti-vaccine activists might not need access to Bet-David's channel any longer, anyway. Earlier this week, Mikovits claimed that she ""got word"" President Trump watched an interview she did with another YouTube channel. That video, which is still on available to watch, has more than 600,000 views."" https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/05/07/1001252/youtube-covid-conspiracy-theories/?fbclid=IwAR12KB555XBvMIrSii2V6wo25Up5P0eNXThscL-aa7gpx5qby90hdsS4TNI
column34: How covid-19 conspiracy theorists are exploiting YouTube culture

column35:
DATELINE RBNews 2021: April 3â€”
Somehow, many Americans seem to have arrived at the conclusion that science operates on the Cafeteria Plan.

That is, they get to choose which science they believe in and support. For example , many people use a GPS map system in the car to help them identify where they are at, where they are going, and how best to get there. 

The Global Positioning System depends not only on Physics, Orbital Mechanics, Microchip technology, and Chemistry, it also relies on adjustments made through the understanding of  Einsteinâ€™s General Theory of Relativity. An auto-driver may or may not consciously believe in Relativity because itâ€™s â€œjust a theory,â€ but without those adaptations, GPS wouldnâ€™t work accurately. So in that regard, they trust those involved sciences.

Immunization biology is also a part of science, and has oodles of proof that it works. Scientists know what they know, and they know what they donâ€™t know, and they know what seems likely but needs more testing. Hence, the rigorous testing protocols before releasing a vaccine, or any medicine to the public.

Yet somehow, so-called antiâ€”vaxxers  and anti-maskers have decided that they know more than true experts: vaccinations cause autism, they say, but such claims are denied by medical experts and experts in autism research. 

The belief system against vaccines has NO empirical evidenced that vaccination causes autism, but the science that says unvaccinated people can  and will get sick if exposed is demonstrated daily in the 2020-2021 Covid-19  pandemic. And many of them will die.

Because religions are faith-based, many â€œreasonsâ€ for anti-vax belief may stem from religious-like rationale â€¦ but most factions of Christianity accept that science doesnâ€™t have to contradict religious precepts.

In 1997, thirty-nine members of a religious cult called Heavenâ€™s Gate, committed suicide in the belief that god had sent a spaceship hidden in or behind the spectacular comet, Hale-Boppe, to whisk them away to godâ€™s kingdom.

The blind support by the FORMER presidentâ€™s followers have been defined by many as cultish or cult-like because they reject any empirical evidence that counterâ€™s his lies, white supremacy, and, frankly, his racist hate-mongering. They behave like a religious cult.

SIDEBAR

Perhaps the reader remember Jonestown, aka The Peoples Temple Agricultural Project. Established in San Francisco by Jim Jones, the cult was moved to an isolated part of Guyana primarily because Jonesâ€™ and his religious group was being investigated by authorities.

In November 1978, at the urging of family members and former cult members, who claimed people were being held against their will, California Congressmen Leo Ryan and a small staff including future Congresswoman Jackie Speier, went to Guayana to investigate the Guayana colony. Upon attempting to leave the report community by airplane, the party was attacked by members of the cult. Ryan and four others were killed. Spier was shot five times and lay wounded for nearly 24 hours before help arrived.

Jones realized the merde had hit his particular fan and told his followers that the time had come to join with god and began to dispense a poisonous concoction often referred to as The Koolaid. Those who refused to drink it, were forced to. 

Over NINE HUNDRED PEOPLE died in this murder suicide, nearly 300 of whom were children. Inclusive, authoritarian cults can be extremely dangerous and their leaders restrict the amount and kind of information their members receive. Ignorance is bliss, if you are a cult leader. Too much real information undermines them â€¦ like science facts versus false pronouncements and claims of special knowledge. 

END SIDEBAR

But science doesnâ€™t work that way. It is NOT a cafeteria plan. Science proceeds whether you or I believe in its principles, or not. And anti vaxxers and anti maskers will continue to get sick, many of who will die â€¦ because they CHOOSE to not believe science and scientists, and the politicians who do. 

Because of this colossal narcissism, these anti-science people will also spread the disease to those who have not yet gotten one of the three currently okayed vaccines by wandering mask-less in public and ignoring social distancing guidelines.

In addition to the amazing embracing of ignorance by so many, the wearing of,  or the not wearing of masks, of all things, was politicized  by the FORMER â€¦ I repeat â€¦ FORMER president â€¦ and if one is a supporter of that  Champion of Ignorance, then you may choose to believe that the act of wearing a mask is not a device to help mitigate the spread of a deadly virus that is approaching a United States death count of 600,000 â€¦ it is instead, somehow, a Democrat plot against the GOP to â€¦ ??? â€¦ to do what? The answers (sic) always seem to involve accusations that canâ€™t be proven, and are way off the subject under consideration.

So, if you are a loyal Nouveau Republican you defiantly refuse to wear a mask; (truncated)

column30: COVID-19 VACCINE VS THE CAZYMOTHERS ANTI- VAXXERS CRAZYMOTHERS DON'T LIKE TO BE CALLED ANTI-VAXXERS WTF = I DON'T WANT TO DIE DUE TO YOUR STUPIDITY Source: The article in regards to ""Crazymothers"" appears in its entirety in Live Science dated 12/4/20. Op-Ed: It never ceases to amaze me how F@cking Stupid an Anti-Vaxxer is. Forrest was 100% correct when he uttered the words Stupid is as Stupid Does. These mothers, and yes they are MOTHERS, claim to be intelligent people, but they do stupid things, that still make them stupid. You are what you do, you are A@S WIPES. To the members of the Crazymother's Association, you should be happy that the media doesn't refer to you for what your really are, Crazy Motherf@ckers. You are individuals who accept no social norms, and do not care about the consequences of your actions. You Crazy Motherf@cker Anti-Vaxxer are people who discount scientifically valid medical research pertaining to vaccines in favor of data produced by a discredited researcher. You believe that you know more about medicine and public health than the overwhelming majority of doctors, scientists, immunologists, and every major health organization across the whole entire planet. I leave for the reader, and perchance a Crazymotherf@cker who happens to come across this post, the reasons why we need to not only to take the Covid-19 vaccine, but a Flu Shot is necessary as well. Thinkers all know that we are presently in all out war with the enemy the Deadly Coronavirus. A plague that has ruined 2020, and that causes an upper respiratory infection caused by some dumbass in China that ate a bat ,and got sick and infected everyone else. The reason to take the COVID-19 vaccine is for the purpose of stopping the pandemic, and it requires using all the tools available. Vaccines work with your immune system so your body will be ready to fight the virus if you are exposed. Other steps, like wearing masks and social distancing, help reduce your chance of being exposed to the virus or spreading it to others. Together, COVID-19 vaccination, and following CDC's recommendations to protect yourself and others, will offer the best protection from COVID-19 Not only is the COVID-19 vaccine necessary to take, so is the Flu Shot. Getting a flu shot this year is particularly important because, like SARS-CoV-2, influenza is a respiratory virus, and we want to do everything we can to minimize having two respiratory outbreaks circulating simultaneously in our population. We THINKERS understand scientific facts and not a bunch of bulls#it. Get wise Crazy Motherfu@ckers, if for no other reason your children's lives depend on it. CRAZYMOTHERS DON'T LIKE TO BE CALLED ANTI-VAXXERS A group of people opposed to vaccinations has requested that media stop referring to them as ""anti-vax."" Instead, they would prefer to be called ""vaccine risk aware."" On Dec. 1, an anti-vaccine group called the Crazymothers raised its plea on Twitter and Instagram, asserting that the term anti-vaxxer is ""derogatory, inflammatory, and marginalizes both women and their experiences."" In response, many social media users chimed in with their own alternative labels for the group, including ""plague enthusiasts,"" ""polio fanciers,"" ""pro-disease"" and ""patient zero."" WHO ARE THE CRAZYMOTHERS??? Founded in 2018, the Crazymothers have just over 1,000 followers on Twitter and about 18,000 on Instagram. The group recently hosted an event in Washington to ""raise awareness to the current epidemic of chronic health conditions, injuries and death from vaccination."" Nearly 3,000 people attended, according to a Crazymothers Instagram post. The group sells merchandise and offers ""expert"" advice on its website. The T-shirts depict anti-vaccine moms as superheroes, and these ""experts"" raise concerns about specific ingredients found in vaccines and the methods by which vaccines are produced. The efforts of groups like this are a problem, because getting vaccinated doesn't just help the person stuck with the needle; it also protects infants and many people with weak immune systems who cannot be vaccinated at all. Vaccines ensure that fewer cases of the disease occur, and therefore, those without the means to defend themselves are more likely to stay safe and healthy. Anti-vaccine groups like the Crazymothers aim to make vaccination optional, which would place these vulnerable populations at risk, according to the APP. The Crazymothers may prefer the term ""vaccine risk aware,"" but in reality, unvaccinated children face far greater health risks than those who do get vaccinated. Meanwhile, the vulnerability to disease of unvaccinated kids places others at risk. The fewer people who get vaccinated, the more people will contract perfectly preventable diseases.

column30: "" . . . purveyors of vaccine misinformation represent a small but vocal minority of the nation's 70,000 chiropractors, many of whom advocate for vaccines ."" Anti-vaccine chiropractors rising force of misinformation PEOPLE TRAVELED FROM AROUND THE COUNTRY TO A WISCONSIN DELLS RESORT FOR A SOLD-OUT CONVENTION ORGANIZED BY CHIROPRACTORS THAT WAS, IN FACT, A SEA OF MISINFORMATION AND CONSPIRACY THEORIES ABOUT VACCINES AND THE PANDEMIC. The flashy postcard, covered with images of syringes, beckoned people to attend Vax-Con '21 to learn ""the uncensored truth"" about COVID-19 vaccines. Participants traveled from around the country to a Wisconsin Dells resort for a sold-out convention that was, in fact, a sea of misinformation and conspiracy theories about vaccines and the pandemic. The featured speaker was the anti-vaccine activist who appeared in the 2020 movie ""Plandemic,"" which pushed false COVID-19 stories into the mainstream. One session after another discussed bogus claims about the health dangers of mask wearing and vaccines. The convention was organized by members of a profession that has become a major purveyor of vaccine misinformation during the pandemic: chiropractors. At a time when the surgeon general says misinformation has become an urgent threat to public health, an investigation by The Associated Press found a vocal and influential group of chiropractors has been capitalizing on the pandemic by sowing fear and mistrust of vaccines. They have touted their supplements as alternatives to vaccines, written doctor's notes to allow patients to get out of mask and immunization mandates, donated large sums of money to anti-vaccine organizations and sold anti-vaccine ads on Facebook and Instagram, the AP discovered. One chiropractor gave thousands of dollars to a Super PAC that hosted an anti-vaccine, pro-Donald Trump rally near the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. They have also been the leading force behind anti-vaccine events like the one in Wisconsin, where hundreds of chiropractors from across the U.S. shelled out $299 or more to attend. The AP found chiropractors were allowed to earn continuing education credits to maintain their licenses in at least 10 states. Public health advocates are alarmed by the number of chiropractors who have hitched themselves to the anti-vaccine movement and used their public prominence and sheen of medical expertise to undermine the nation's response to a COVID-19 pandemic that has killed more than 700,000 Americans. ""People trust them. They trust their authority, but they also feel like they're a nice alternative to traditional medicine,"" said Erica DeWald of Vaccinate Your Family, who tracks figures in the anti-vaccine movement. ""Mainstream medicine will refer people out to a chiropractor not knowing that they could be exposed to misinformation. You go because your back hurts, and then suddenly you don't want to vaccinate your kids."" The purveyors of vaccine misinformation represent a small but vocal minority of the nation's 70,000 chiropractors, many of whom advocate for vaccines. In some places, chiropractors have helped organize vaccine clinics or been authorized to give COVID-19 shots. And chiropractic is not the only health care profession whose members have been associated with COVID-19 misinformation: Some medical doctors have spread dangerous falsehoods about vaccines, a problem so concerning that the national group representing state medical boards warned in July that doctors who push vaccine disinformation could have their licenses revoked. But the pandemic gave a new platform to a faction of chiropractors who had been stirring up anti-vaccine misinformation long before COVID-19 arrived, driven by interpretations of 19th century chiropractic beliefs that medicine interferes with the body's natural flow of energy. Chiropractic was founded in 1895 by D.D. Palmer, a ""magnetic healer"" who argued that most disease was a result of misaligned vertebrae. Its early leaders rejected the use of surgery and drugs, as well as the idea that germs cause disease. Instead, they believed the body has an innate intelligence, and the power to heal itself if it is functioning properly, and that chiropractic care can help it do that. This led many to reject vaccines -- even though vaccines are not within their scope of practice. Instead, they treat conditions through spine and musculoskeletal adjustments, as well as exercise and nutritional counseling. A 2015 Gallup survey found an estimated 33.5 million adults had seen a chiropractor in the previous 12 months. Even before the pandemic, many chiropractors became active in the so-called ""health freedom"" movement, advocating in state legislatures from Massachusetts to South Dakota to allow more people to skip vaccinations. Since 2019, the AP found, chiropractors and chiropractor-backed groups have worked to influence vaccine-related legislation and policy in at least 24 states. For example, an organization started by a (truncated)

column30: For the first months of Joe Bidenâ€™s presidency, his handling of the coronavirus pandemic was a remarkable success story. Vaccinations accelerated, caseloads dropped dramatically, and the country began working its way toward a sense of normalcy. But that story is entering a complicated new chapter: The more transmissible Delta variant is surging in areas with stubbornly low inoculation rates. Pleas from politicians, experts, and pop stars donâ€™t seem to be working on vaccine hold-outs. And breakthrough casesâ€”most of which appear to be mild, thanks to the vaccinesâ€”are fueling some anxiety among Americans still reeling from more than a year and a half of pandemic life. To be sure, the sometimes-breathless reporting on breakthrough infections might be a problem in and of itself. Outletsâ€”some well-intentioned, some perhaps trying to score ðŸ“Œpolitical pointsâ€”have blared scary headlines about recent infections among vaccinated people, including Texas Democrats who left the state for D.C. to prevent Republicans from enacting draconian anti-voting laws. But those reports can sometimes bury the crucial part of the story: The vast majority of breakthrough cases are either asymptomatic or mild. As a number of observers have pointed out, such reporting could stoke unnecessary fears among people who are largely protected from COVID, while giving the unvaccinated even less incentive to get their shotsâ€”a problem, considering this latest surge has been a â€œpandemic of the unvaccinated,â€ as Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Director Rochelle Walensky put it last week. Still, the surge is creating a vexing scenario for lawmakers and public health officials. The Biden White House, whose campaign to bring the coronavirus to heel has been hobbled by the MAGA right, is racing to keep this latest surge from derailing the progress it has made. â€œThe clock is running. We all know that,â€ a senior Biden adviser told CNN, referring to spiking caseloads. â€œThe president certainly knows that.â€ On Capitol Hill, breakthrough infections, including in House Speaker Nancy Pelosiâ€™s office, have stoked fears of a dangerous new wave and the possibility of a return to the kinds of protocols that lawmakers only recently lifted. â€œThe mood is one of frustration and concern,â€ Democrat #JamieRaskin, who has begun wearing a mask on the House floor again, told Politico. â€œItâ€™s a disappointing turn of events.â€ While the Delta variant is almost exclusively #killing those who are #notvaccinated, vaccinated people in high risk groups, which includes many in Congress, may be more vulnerable to breakthrough cases. â€œIâ€™m feeling a lot more anxiety about it,â€ Democrat #SusanWild told the outlet. There may be an upside to that anxiety: it has inspired House Minority #WhipSteveScalise, a high-profile holdout, to get his first shot. â€œWith the #Deltavariant becoming a lot more aggressive and seeing another spike, it was a good time to do it,â€ Scalise told reporters. The surge has also led some at Fox News, which has downplayed COVID and promoted anti-vax conspiracy theories for months, to change their tone on vaccines, with prominent personalities at the #rightwing network like #SteveDoocy and #SeanHannity urging viewers to get their shots. â€œPlease take COVID seriously,â€ Hannity told his audience Monday night. â€œI canâ€™t say it enough.â€ But, as my colleague Caleb Ecarma pointed out Tuesday, the network continues to send ðŸ“Œmixed signals about #vaccinations, and for all the sincere appeals from people like Mitch McConnell, many in the party are still treating COVID as a front in their #culturewar.#RandPaul remains more concerned about his performative offensive against Anthony Fauci, as does #Florida Governor #RonDeSantis, even as ðŸ“Œinfections surge in his state. #TedCruz and others continue their hysterics about the possibility of vaccine mandates. And #extremists like #MarjorieTaylorGreene who has more than once equated the Biden administrationâ€™s efforts to vaccinate Americans to the #Holocaustâ€”are still telling dangerous #lies about the pandemic and vaccines and portraying themselves as victims of government overreach. (Greene and two other Republicans who were fined for refusing to abide by Capitol Hill mask mandates this spring had their punishments upheld by the House Ethics Committee Tuesday, which the QAnon Congresswoman whined was an â€œabuse of discretion.â€) With politics polluting public health efforts, officials have struggled to get through to the unvaccinated, many of whom have told pollsters that they regard inoculations as more dangerous than the virus itself. The results are fast becoming a maddeningly avoidable tragedy: While many Americans are emerging from the pandemic, the mutated virus is ravaging some parts of the country worse than it did in 2020. â€œMy sense of hope is dwindling,â€ a nurse in southwestern Missouri, where caseloads are stressing hospital systems, told the Atlanticâ€™s Ed Yong. â€œIâ€™m losing a little bit of faith in (truncated)

column34: This is a re-share of a post
column35:
Letter from TCM practitioners... to
 Lee Hsien Loong.... 

TCM Practitioners believe in early treatment too! Indeed, flu and colds have traditionally been known to be best treated early. 

In their letter, they highlighted that during SARS, TCM did play a role. Since then, both Western and Chinese medicine made strides on the treatment of coronaviruses. (For English translation of letter content, see - https://m.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10158451332163715&id=575383714&set=a.459119113714&source=48&ref=content_filter.)

Why then are treatments thrown out? Early treatment is NOT an ""anti-vax"" or ""fake science"" position.

I feel sad to confess that I am not hopeful this letter will be considered. And I fear authorities would rather believe in banning treatments than empowering citizens with knowledge. This lack of self-reliant knowledge coupled with complete dependence on government caused panic and exposed major cracks when local cases began to rise sharply weeks ago. Many citizens were caught unprepared and unable to cope with the lapses of MOH's follow-up of healthcare and quarantine orders (thankful for the frontliners' effort but not appreciating the policies set by the top). 

To clarify, I am not endorsing Lianhua Qingwen (due to my lack of research into it) but I think these medical opinions should be seriously considered as the ""no treatment"" narrative is obviously not a reasonable medical advice. For it worsens a Covid-infected person's health quite logically. Why wait for Delta virus to multiply freely which the spike proteins - now multiplied - wreck havoc and cause inflammatory outcomes which IS what kills a Covid patient? 

On the other hand, research strongly shows that with early treatment, patients - regardless of vaccination status - prevented hospitalisation and deaths by up to 85%. One particular study involving >700 patients even show a 100% reduction in respiratory complications, hospitalisations and deaths - https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2052297521000792. 

Hence, where is our commonsense? These TCM practitioners see the problem, wrote this letter and volunteer to help. Governments' roles should be to facilitate self-reliant communities or at least allow space for that, not cultivate an ever-dependent helpless population, especially in the midst of crises. Worse, that volunteers' goodwill will be threatened with arrests, fines and jail terms. Now that medical practitioners have stepped up and want to help, why not? Surely measured cooperation is a better way than total censorship of the abilities and desires to help? No?

column30: In Siloam Springs, right wing extremists act like right wing extremists ------------------------------------ Governor Hutchinson gets more angry response in Siloam Springs to vaccination sales pitch BY Max Brantley ON July 30, 20212:32 pm UNDER FIRE: Governor Hutchinson in Siloam Springs. NO MASKS ON KIDS: That was the pitch from this speaker. Governor Hutchinsonâ€™s town hall in Siloam Springs today was again marked with loud protests to his encouragement for more vaccinations. You can see the full program on KNWAâ€™s Facebook page. A loud ovation followed a suggestion that it would be a violation of federal health law to require an employee of a private hospital to wear a mask or be vaccinated. This is a popular and misguided talking point among the Trump/vax resistance. The HIPAA Privacy Rule protects individualsâ€™ medical records and other personal health information. It does not bar private businesses from establishing health rules, such as requiring restaurant workers to wash their hands after restroom use. Another cheer followed a suggestion that the vaccine doesnâ€™t prevent transmission and a question about testing of vaccine on young children. No one is going to require a shot, he said. The crowd groaned loudly when the governor said more people would die without more vaccination. Health Director Jose Romero also drew groans when saying infection by COVID isnâ€™t as good a protection as the vaccine. Another cheer erupted for a man who said vaccinated people have gotten the virus. True. The percentage is tiny. But donâ€™t confuse this crowd with facts â€” that the vaccine is 90 percent effective and that those who get ill despite the vaccine have less serious illnesses. A man rose to encourage vaccination and got some applause, not nearly so loud as the booing continent. The governor remained calm and several times encourage people to be respectful. â€œWould yâ€™all like to be recognized or would you just like to yell?â€ he said at one point. Other comments reflected debunked mischaracterization of the virus among vaccinated people in Israel and the United Kingdom. Fact-checking falls to Facebook falsehoods ewhen the debate is not science but tribalism. One member of the audience said he wasnâ€™t convinced COVID was real. Another said nobody knew what was in the vaccine. Romero said he could provide that information. Others said the vaccine was â€œexperimentalâ€ and long-term effects were unknown. (Cheers.) Romero was booed when he said no fetal tissue was used in two vaccines after a speaker â€” a nurse with eight children â€” said many feared the vaccine because of use of such material. One vaccine, he said, did develop vaccines from genetic material derived long ago. The potential of mandates in hospitals and the military, even with religious exceptions, angered several speakers. Itâ€™s like the Arkansas legislature. The world â€” public and private â€” should conform to THEIR beliefs, no matter how harmful to others. Hutchinsonâ€™s patience was remarkable. This session made Mountain Home look like a lovefest. One speaker said John Q. Public should be listened to rather than just health experts. One speaker came to oppose lifting the ban on mask mandates in schools. â€œThe cure is worse than the disease,â€ she said. She said Rep. Robin Lundstrum said her mail was running 15-1 against lifting the ban. She was lustily cheered. Hutchinson emphasized his proposal was only to let government closest to the people make a decision and they could decide not to require masks. Sounds like it would be a â€œheavy liftâ€ to get it approved in this part of Arkansas. Bottom line: Itâ€™s hopeless. https://arktimes.com/arkansas-blog/2021/07/30/governor-hutchinson-gets-more-angry-response-in-siloam-springs-to-vaccination-sales-pitch
column34: This is a re-share of a post
column35:
In Siloam Springs, right wing extremists act like right wing extremists

------------------------------------

Governor Hutchinson gets more angry response in Siloam Springs to vaccination sales pitch

BY
 Max Brantley

 
ON
July 30, 20212:32 pm

 
UNDER FIRE: Governor Hutchinson in Siloam Springs.
 
NO MASKS ON KIDS: That was the pitch from this speaker.

Governor Hutchinsonâ€™s town hall in Siloam Springs today was again marked with loud protests to his encouragement for more vaccinations.

You can see the full program on KNWAâ€™s Facebook page.

A loud ovation followed a suggestion that it would be a violation of federal health law to require an employee of a private hospital to wear a  mask or be vaccinated. This is a popular and misguided talking point among the Trump/vax resistance. The HIPAA Privacy Rule protects individualsâ€™ medical records and other personal health information. It does not bar private businesses from establishing health rules, such as requiring restaurant workers to wash their hands after restroom use.

Another cheer followed a suggestion that the vaccine doesnâ€™t prevent transmission and a question about testing of vaccine on young children. No one is going to require a shot, he said. The crowd groaned loudly when the governor said more people would die without more vaccination.

Health Director Jose Romero also drew groans when saying infection by COVID isnâ€™t as good a protection as the vaccine.

Another cheer erupted for a man who said vaccinated people have gotten the virus. True. The percentage is tiny. But donâ€™t confuse this crowd with facts â€” that the vaccine is 90 percent effective and that those who get ill despite the vaccine have less serious illnesses.

A man rose to encourage vaccination and got some applause, not nearly so loud as the booing continent. The governor remained calm and several times encourage people to be respectful. â€œWould yâ€™all like to be recognized or would you just like to yell?â€ he said at one point.

Other comments reflected debunked mischaracterization of the virus among vaccinated people in Israel and the United Kingdom.

Fact-checking falls to Facebook falsehoods ewhen the debate is not science but tribalism.

One member of the audience said he wasnâ€™t convinced COVID was real. Another said nobody knew what was in the vaccine. Romero said he could provide that information. Others said the vaccine was â€œexperimentalâ€ and long-term effects were unknown. (Cheers.)

Romero was booed when he said no fetal tissue was used in two vaccines after a speaker â€” a nurse with eight children â€” said many feared the vaccine because of use of such material. One vaccine, he said, did develop vaccines from genetic material derived long ago.

The potential of mandates in hospitals and the military, even with religious exceptions, angered several speakers. Itâ€™s like the Arkansas legislature. The world â€” public and private â€” should conform to THEIR beliefs, no matter how harmful to others.

Hutchinsonâ€™s patience was remarkable. This session made Mountain Home look like a lovefest.

One speaker said John Q. Public should be listened to rather than just health experts.

One speaker came to oppose lifting the ban on mask mandates in schools. â€œThe cure is worse than the disease,â€ she said. She said Rep. Robin Lundstrum said her mail was running 15-1 against lifting the ban. She was lustily cheered. Hutchinson emphasized his proposal was only to let government closest to the people make a decision and they could decide not to require masks. Sounds like it would be a â€œheavy liftâ€ to get it approved in this part of Arkansas.

Bottom line: Itâ€™s hopeless.

Need your COVID-19 booster or a first-time vaccine? Attend the State of Illinois and Cook County Public Health's Pop-Up Vaccine Event in Arlington Heights this Sunday! From 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Pfizer, Moderna, and J&J booster shots will be available for all eligible individuals. First and second shots will also be available for individuals 12+. No appointment is necessary, and you are not required to show photo ID or an insurance card to get vaccinated! The Arlington Heights Health Center is located at 3250 N. Arlington Heights Rd., Suite 300.

Individuals are eligible for a booster 6 months after they received their second dose of Pfizer or Moderna, or 2 months after a single dose of the J&J vaccine. Adults age 18+ may receive any vaccine as a booster.

column30: Why has the nation become gripped with conspiracy theories â€” including so many revolving around the shots that could end this devastating pandemic? â€œItâ€™s precisely because weâ€™ve had 450,000 deaths, and so much uncertainty and so much fear, that thereâ€™s fertile ground for this stuff to take hold,â€ says Ashish Jha, a physician and dean of Brown Universityâ€™s School of Public Health. The pandemic is also occurring in the context of a 20-year decline of American trust in institutions, says Ethan Zuckerman, who formerly directed the Center for Civic Media at MIT. He describes the QAnon cult as a reservoir at the bottom of that slippery slope. â€œQ is what happens when you take that mistrust in a really damaging direction,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s usually people who lost trust in one institution and then found a coherent worldview that says, â€˜Donâ€™t just mistrust this one institution â€” mistrust all the institutions. All of them are in it together.â€™ â€ This full rejection of confidence in doctors and drug companies, in media and philanthropy, in politicians and government agencies, Zuckerman says, is â€œhow the anti-vax movement underwent almost a merger with QAnon.â€... ""Exploring conspiracy theories and mass delusion can inadvertently popularize misinformation. So inoculate yourself with facts: The novel vaccines produced by Pfizer and Moderna are revolutionary and take advantage of our own cellular machinery to safeguard recipients against future coronavirus infection."" ~ Rolling Stone, How the Anti-Vaxxers Got Red-Pilled by Tim Dickinson

column30: March 5, 2021 Dear Neighbor, This week, Maryland is up to 15.8% of our population vaccinated, and Montgomery County is above that average at 16.3%. In great news, 40% of Marylanders 65 and over are now vaccinated. This number will increase steadily in the next few weeks. We are also doing very well in metrics for administering our second doses, which some other states are finding more challenging. In the New York Times ranking of states based on the percentage of population vaccinated with at least one dose, we are ranked 31st out of 50 states. Our weekly vaccine allocation went up from 118,000 to about 200,000 this week. This includes almost 50,000 Johnson & Johnson vaccines which will be administered over several weeks (we donâ€™t expect another J&J allocation until mid-March). President Biden also announced plans to ramp up vaccine production to a level that will have a vaccine for every adult by the end of May. This is amazing news and requires we really ramp up our ability to distribute vaccines. While there is great news to report, there are also some areas of concern. For example, state data reveals that while Latinos make up 11% of the Maryland population, they have received only 4% of the vaccine. And data also reveals that in Montgomery County, the vaccination rate for people aged 75-84 exceeds the vaccination rate for people over 85. Our oldest community members and racial and ethnic minorities still need help getting vaccinated. We have technological, transportation, and logistical barriers to address. Ernst & Young Contract Why has Maryland been ranked so low in the percentage of doses received actually being administered? Getting to the bottom of that is one reason we have contracted with Ernst & Young. In addition to providing support to the Vaccine Equity Task Force, these consultants have helped the state identify 25,000 doses that were allocated from Maryland to the Federal Long Term Care partnership but left unused. They will be coming back to the state for redistribution. On top of that, they have identified an issue with the reported federal allocation to Maryland. The Governor reported that there are more than 200,000 doses that have been sent to Federal agencies to vaccinate their Maryland workforce in this accounting. These doses are not part of the state-controlled allocation, and many are still unused (much to the frustration of our federal workforce!). I will share more information on this as it becomes available. Infant and Toddler Childcare & K-12 Teachers President Biden has asked the partners in the Federal Pharmacy Partnership to prioritize educators in March. That means CVS and Walgreens are now taking appointments for in-home (including nannies) and center-based childcare providers and public and private school teachers. President Bidenâ€™s goal is to have every childcare provider and PK-12 teacher vaccinated with at least their first shot by the end of March. The other pharmacies (Giant, Safeway, Rite Aid, WalMart) participate in the state program and may not choose to prioritize educators. The state mass vaccination sites are taking appointments for childcare workers and other educators. Click HERE for my list of contact information for vaccine sites including pharmacies, hospitals, and mass vaccination sites. Montgomery County (in partnership with Johns Hopkins/Suburban Hospital) is on track to having offered a vaccine to every MCPS employee heading back to the classroom in the first phase by March 15. Mobile Vaccination Units & Home Visit Vaccines The state is launching three mobile vaccination units. They will be initially deployed to the Eastern Shore and Western Maryland. We will also be using FEMA trucks to do mobile vaccinations. A number of other jurisdictions, including Prince George's County, also have mobile vaccination units. Montgomery County is still working on getting vaccines to our homebound population. Montgomery Countyâ€™s pilot of this program was delayed, but began this week and will expand in the coming weeks. If you are among the 3,500+ Montgomery County residents who pre-registered for the vaccine and are homebound, you will not be left behind. Six Flags Data For people with reliable transportation, the drive-through Six Flags mass vaccination site has proven incredibly popular. This drive-through site is vaccinating more than 2000 people a day, and the largest number of appointments have gone to Montgomery County residents. Of the first 34,396 doses administered, 10,603 went to Montgomery County residents. 5,236 Anne Arundel, 4,179 Howard County, only 3,538 to Prince George's County. New Mass Vax Sites The Waldorf Blue Crabs/Regency Furniture Stadium opened yesterday. (about 75 minutes from Bethesda) Wicomico Youth and Civic Center on the Eastern Shore will open on or before March 18th. (about 145 minutes from Bethesda) Hagerstown Premium Outlets will open at the end of March. (50-60 minutes from Bethesda) These are in addition to the Six (truncated)

column30: #WhoDoYouBelieve #EpistemicCrisis ""A good way of describing them would be as recommender engines. They monitor your digital trail and note what interests you â€“ as evidenced by what youâ€™ve browsed or purchased online. Amazon, for example, regularly offers me suggestions for items that are â€œbased on your browsing historyâ€. It also shows me a list of what people who purchased the item Iâ€™m considering also bought. YouTubeâ€™s engine notes what kinds of videos I have watched â€“ and logs how much of each I have watched before clicking onwards â€“ and then presents on the right-hand side of the screen an endlessly-scrolling list of videos that might interest me based on what Iâ€™ve just watched. In the early days of the web, few, if any, of these engines existed. But from 2001 onwards they became increasingly common and are now almost ubiquitous. Several factors drove this expansion. One was the need to help users cope with the information overload that came with the web: recommender engines could sift through the torrent and create a personalised distillation just for you. But the prime driving force was the business model we now call surveillance capitalism â€“ logging our online behaviour in order to make increasingly refined predictions about our preferences and likely needs that could be sold to advertisers anxious to sell us stuff."" ... ""Just out of interest, this week I tried a search in the books section on Amazon.co.uk for â€œcancer cureâ€. Of the first 11 available titles that came up, only one looked like a conventional scientific treatment of the topic. The others focused on herbs, oils and â€œnatural cures they donâ€™t want you to know aboutâ€. This is not because Amazon has a grudge against scientific medicine, but because there is something about unconventional books in this area that its machine-learning algorithm is detecting â€“ perhaps from reviews posted by evangelists for non-scientific approaches. (DiResta thought that this may indeed be the explanation: Amazon did not confirm this.) But itâ€™s conceivable that in really controversial â€“ and currently topical â€“ areas such as vaccination, coordinated user reviews by anti-vaxxers might successfully game the algorithm. And in the past Amazon [has been accused](https://www.vox.com/2016/9/6/12815250/amazon-health-products-bogus)of being â€œa giant purveyor of medical quackeryâ€. What it really means, I guess, is that, in the online world, information warfare is now ubiquitous. And since books are really just containers for information and ideas, it was predictable that marketplaces such as Amazon would become targets for manipulation. Truth is always the first casualty in war.""

column34: Jake
column35:
Changi Airport Cluster Analysis (Data file in comments below)

Highlights of this cluster:
1. The no. of symptomatic cases in the vaccinated & unvaccinated are almost the same, only differ by 1 case more in the unvaccinated.
2. Interestingly there are 5 more asymptomatic cases in the unvaccinated group. Why is this so? Isn't vaccination supposed to reduce symptoms?
3. The symptoms are generally similar to normal flu. 
4. Both groups have 1 case of anosmia.
5. Shockingly, there is 1 case of shortness of breath in the vaccinated group!
6. The 4 students in the unvaccinated group are all asymptomatic! Thank God!

Questions:
1. Why is there not much difference in cases bet vax & unvax? 
2. Are the other pri sch students who tested positive also asymptomatic? How serious is their illness for those who have symptoms? What kind of treatment was given? Is there reason for parents to be worried? If not, please make an announcement so that parents won't panic and keep their children at home. Children need to go outdoors daily!
3. Why is the efficacy of the vaccine so low? Could it be a storage problem? Could it be the procedures during administration of the vax? Shouldn't the authorities put a halt to the program and do a thorough investigation?
4. Is the PCR test accurate? How many swab tests are done on each person on average? Why is there a need to do more than 3 swab tests per person? Could the PCR test be picking up the spike proteins created by the vaccine in the vaccinated group? What other clinical diagnosis is done to confirm the positive PCR test, especially for those who are asymptomatic? 

Seems like the efficacy of the vaccine is very low (13.04%) if HALF the people tested are vaccinated. However, if the percentage of those tested who are vaccinated falls below 46%, the vaccinated becomes easier to get infected. Just look at the infection rate if only 25% tested are vaccinated.

This certainly warrants a detailed study. I hope the relevant authorities can release more data such as total number of people in the cluster tested and percentage of those tested who are vaccinated. Only then can we calculate the actual efficacy.

column34: Dr Sara Marzouk
column35:
Yesterday, Indonesia reported a record 47,899 new cases of COVID-19. The country has now recorded more than 2.6 million cases and 68,219 deaths.

The situation is incredibly dire, and the per capita death toll in Indonesia has now surpassed that of India.

The percentage of positive cases per population tested, known as the positivity rate, is a whopping 30% in many places. The dramatic rise in being attributed to the highly contagious delta variant.

The  Indonesian Doctors Association has reported that at least 434 Indonesian doctors have died from COVID-19. Trainee doctors are being pushed to the front line of Indonesia's COVID-19 disaster due to a shortage of trained medical professionals. 

This is happening on Australiaâ€™s doorstep right now. 

And thatâ€™s why I have absolutely ZERO tolerance for  COVID deniers, the rabid anti-vaxxers and the anti-lockdown rabble at the moment. 

State governments implement lockdowns and introduce restrictions to save lives, using data modelled by epidemiologists whoâ€™ve dedicated their life to their craft, yet Ali from the Kebab shop thinks the videos heâ€™s watched on YouTube make him a better authority on the subject of infectivity and R0 numbers. 

Molecular biologists and researchers, with decades of experience and knowledge, have worked tirelessly to create efficacious and safe vaccines to address this pandemic, yet Tiffany from the Salon read some circulating screenshots and knows more about research trial protocols than they do. 

Doctors around the world have literally put their lives on the line treating the fallen. Too many have perished, like our Indonesian medical brethren. But Bob from the Gym listened to a podcast and now is an expert in treatment protocols and filling out death certificates.

Itâ€™s so incredibly demoralising. 

And itâ€™s so incredibly mentally draining for those in lockdown to have to deal with these ignorant extremists that once again. On cue, theyâ€™ve started spreading the same lies, spinning the same anti-vax propaganda, and using genuine mental health issues as the vehicle to argue against health measures that aim to stop the same carnage we are seeing in Indonesia at this very moment. 

These people will never accept how privileged weâ€™ve been until they are FaceTiming a loved one dying in ICU in a hospital overwhelmed by COVID.

How absolutely and utterly selfish, making this pandemic so much harder than it already is. 

To everyone who is doing the right thing, who are making sacrifices to keep us all safe until our vaccination rates allow us to live with COVID, thank you.

To those who continue to contribute to the misinformation pandemic: Shame on you.

- Sara

He describes the QAnon cult as a reservoir at the bottom of that slippery slope. â€œQ is what happens when you take that mistrust in a really damaging direction,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s usually people who lost trust in one institution and then found a coherent worldview that says, â€˜Donâ€™t just mistrust this one institution â€” mistrust all the institutions. All of them are in it together.â€™ â€ This full rejection of confidence in doctors and drug companies, in media and philanthropy, in politicians and government agencies, Zuckerman says, is â€œhow the anti-vax movement underwent almost a merger with QAnon.â€... Anti mask and anti vax Republicans are like a sheep herder killing off all the sheep dogs to protect the sheep from all the wolves and then ignore all the dead sheep and getting mad when someone tells them to get more sheep dogs!

If We Canâ€™t or Wonâ€™t Figure This Out We Might as Well Open the Gates to the Barbarians . There is a story that a Roman aristocrat opened the gates of Rome to the Visigoths in 410AD. He did it because this was the third siege of Rome that he had endured and he didnâ€™t want to do it anymore. Now there is a lot of fog with that story but it does make a great point. We are becoming as a nation a lot like Rome. We have been on top for a while and figure that we no longer have to work for our place. We see it in the Karens of the world and their male counterparts, the Teds. We see drama everywhere for everything and so much of it is fake BS. But they get away with it so others follow in their footsteps and the media gives them notoriety for it. The national symbol should be that for Narcissism because that is what we are now about. The entire anti-vax movement and resistance to getting a shot is so much like the Roman aristocrat. â€œI just donâ€™t want to be bothered!â€ . But the one that borders on malignant Narcissism is how Joe Biden is being blamed for inflation. There is a whole lot of insanity (Narcissism) at work here. Before economics went â€œVoodooâ€ with Reagan and both parties fell in lockstep to protect it, there was real economics. During the pandemic, many of us bought way more things than we have ever before. Amazon was some kind of therapy because so many were deprived of their constant interaction and their phone wasnâ€™t good enough. So they bought everything under the sun. Now into the second and third years of this pandemic, we still are. We buy the vast majority of it from China and it has to be paid for. The oil cartel has taken advantage of it to screw us to the wall, every business is raising prices well beyond their costs and for that reason they are bringing in, record profits. I REPEAT THEY ARE MAKING RECORD PROFITS!!!. And yet in so many Karen and Ted minds, it is beyond them to figure this out. The media makes sure everyone knows who to blame and GOP/ Con politicians make sure too. But this is not the government at work here, it is what we have allowed as a faux monopoly economy at work here. . Societies usually have ebbs and flows. We are going through a hell of an ebb right now. But itâ€™s not just that, which is so scary. Itâ€™s that smart people are so easily misled while readily apparent facts go unseen, discarded, and ignored. THAT! That is what is so scary. That stupid and self-centered rules and it is right there to be seen in the media, every night and day. If we cannot stop this fall into self-centered stupidity, then we are indeed doomed. RC Romine

The Chain . Stevie Nickâ€™s wrote a song about her experience with abuse, â€œThe Chainâ€. But the lyric that tells the tale is â€œYou would never break the chain (Never break the chain)â€ That is indeed the situation we find ourselves in. . This is not necessarily a story of good and bad. But it is one of winners and losers in the Reagan Revolution and the Conâ€™s takeover of the economy. The Cons themselves are bad, they have driven this nation into an authoritarian disaster. But those that went with the Reagan Revolution simply see themselves as those that were smart enough to go with the flow and thrived from it. They are so tied into the abuse of the lower and middle class that they see it as their due. They see economic segregation as simply the way of the world, they see the off-shoring of American jobs as others wanting too much. Even though there is no limit to what they want. As it becomes more and more apparent that they screwed the pooch, we see and more of the Karen and Ted effect. Itâ€™s not about greed and its aftermath, itâ€™s about freedom and themselves being exploited by poor people. Itâ€™s really about Narcissism and the faith that they can never be wrong, especially when they are. So Trump was no aberration, he is simply the norm to them. . What is now Trumpism has always been here. Itâ€™s about seeing the world through the prism of greed and selfishness. That everyone else is wrong, socialists, communists looking to take away everything from them. Taxes are the wages of governmental sin, God is with them because, and of course God is. The Karenâ€™s and Teds see themselves as righteous winners, no matter how much they screw up OUR nation. We should really have no surprise when the anti-vaxers showed up because they are just Karenâ€™s and Tedâ€™s looking for a cause to preach to others. Right or wrong, it doesnâ€™t matter. Itâ€™s all about them anyway. Anti-vax was just there and available. In so many households in America, particularly in the upper-middle class, it is the Karen and Ted show. Their much-deserved wealth and winner status is dissolving as the corporations become more and more greedy. Their life on credit is balancing on a pin, their lifestyles and image are all wrapped up into their illusion. Their 401k, is simply a con and so they make sure to vote for anyone that will protect the con and their illusion. If democracy dies, if the poor people suffer, then so be it. As long as the police can keep it under control. Abuse is the name of the game and they are vested in its image, things, and politics. . â€œKeeping it goingâ€ is all they can do. They live to retire and live in luxury. If they can just keep the Dems and the progressives/ socialists out. That somehow with Republicans in charge of swing state government they were cheated! Their 401k will die along with their image and dreams. The chain of economic, social, and political abuse must be kept intact for them to thrive. Going to church substitutes for morals, their ass in the pew makes it all right. â€œHave to keep it all going or the world I need will die.â€ The Karenâ€™s and Teds, the fragile that need to abuse others to be happy and whole. This is what narcissism is all about. They deserve to abuse, to have things to show the world they are special, superior. The Conâ€™s game of thrones is all there is. The lies and message give reason to their need to abuse, their Karenâ€™s and Teds screaming and shaking, blaming everyone for their actions is what they have become. Just like Donald Trump, they are winners, the privileged, and the protected. It is time to quit letting them get away with it! RC Romine

column30: Robert F. Kennedy, Jr, Chairman, Childrenâ€™s Health Defense, wrote on April 23, 2020: 'THE BILL GATES EFFECT: WHOâ€™s DTP VACCINE KILLED MORE CHILDREN IN AFRICA THAN THE DISEASES IT TARGETED' ""Anyone defending the Bill Gates/WHO global vaccine program needs to explain this study: [Mogensen et al 2017](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5360569/). Prior to 2017, neither HHS nor WHO ever performed the kind of vaccinated/unvaccinated (or placebo) study necessary to ascertain if the DTP vaccine actually yields beneficial health outcomes. The DTP vaccine was [discontinued in the US and western nations](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4975064/) in the [1990s](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4975064/) following thousands of reports of death and brain damage. But Bill Gates and his surrogates, GAVI and WHO, [made DTP a priority for African babies](https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/publications/progress-reports/Gavi-Progress-Report-2018.pdf). The Danish government and Novo Nordisk Foundation commissioned this study by a team of the worldâ€™s leading experts on African vaccination. The two most prominent names, Drs. Soren Mogensen and Peter Aaby, are both vocal vaccine supporters. They were shocked when they examined years of data from a so called â€œnatural experimentâ€ in Guinea Bissau where 50% of children die before age five. In that west African nation, half the children were vaccinated with the DTP vaccine at three months and the other half at six months. Dr. Mogenson and his team found that girls vaccinated with the DTP vaccine died at 10 times the rate of unvaccinated kids. While the vaccinated children were protected from Diphtheria, Tetanus and Pertussis, they were far more susceptible to other deadly diseases than unvaccinated peers. The vaccine apparently compromised their immune systems. Thanks to Gates, DTP is the worldâ€™s most popular vaccine. For African nations, [GAVI and WHO use DTP vaccine uptake to gauge national compliance](https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/publications/progress-reports/Gavi-Progress-Report-2018.pdf) with vaccine recommendations. GAVI can [financially punish](https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/document/performance-based-funding-information-sheetpdf.pdf) nations that donâ€™t fully comply. The researchers suggested that the [DTP vaccine is killing more children than the diseases it targets.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5360569/) Itâ€™s possible that millions of children are adversely affected. Although the New York Times and other Gates boosters will accuse me of promoting â€œvaccine misinformationâ€, this is a peer reviewed publication in a respected journal by the worldâ€™s most authoritative vaccine scientists describing catastrophic outcomes. Shouldnâ€™t we be scrutinizing Bill Gatesâ€™ record in Africa before we let him dictate which medicines we need to take? By muzzling legitimate criticism as â€œanti-vaxâ€, the media avoids honest debate on many damning studies like Mogensen."" [https://childrenshealthdefense.org/news/the-bill-gates-effect-whos-dtp-vaccine-kills-more-children-in-africa-than-the-diseases-it-targets/](https://childrenshealthdefense.org/news/the-bill-gates-effect-whos-dtp-vaccine-kills-more-children-in-africa-than-the-diseases-it-targets/)

column30: The CDC has relaxed its COVID-19 guidelines for schools: --Vaccinated teachers and students don't need to wear masks inside school buildings --they are not advising schools to require shots for teachers and vaccine-eligible kids. And it's not offering guidance on how teachers can know which students are vaccinated or how parents will know which teachers are immunized. --Schools should continue to space kids â€” and their desks â€” 3 feet apart in classrooms, the CDC says. But the agency emphasized that spacing should not be an obstacle to getting kids back in schools. And it said distancing is not required among fully vaccinated students or staff. --Separating students into smaller groups, or cohorts, continues to be a good way to help reduce spread of the virus. But the CDC discouraged putting vaccinated and unvaccinated kids in separate groups, saying schools shouldn't stigmatize any group or perpetuate academic, racial or other tracking. My immediate thoughts: How are schools going to enforce ANY of this--but especially mask wearing for those that are over 12 but are not vaccinated? The ""honor system"" does not work. We need to have mask wearing for all kids until all age groups are eligible, and then the vaccine needs to be required for school attendance just like MMR, Polio, and Chicken pox. Vaccines are part of the social contract - if you don't want to be part of the solution, there's always home school, private school, charter school, etc. Here's a little analogy: All peanut products are banned in schools to protect a very small percentage of *individuals* from lethal allergic reactions that are NOT contagious, and no one is complaining about that. (I'm not complaining either, this is an analogy.) So why are we willing to do THAT to protect a few individuals, but we aren't willing to have everyone in the school masked and distanced (at the very least) until we can get everyone in the school vaxxed and require the vax for those who have no medical reason not to get it? My biggest concern is that the CDC's illogical decision emboldens people like the one below. Please DO show up to the Wake County School Board meeting on July 20th. FOR EXACTLY THE OPPOSITE REASONS this woman lists.

column30: Dear Neighbor, This weekend, my daughter Maeve celebrated her 17th birthday together with her friends. I was able to hug my cousins and Aunt and Uncle for the first time in two years. And, I saw a movie with my girlfriends. In a theatre! I hope you too are beginning to see a light at the end of this long tunnel. Things certainly are looking up- thank you science! But there is still a tremendous amount of work to be done as we recover physically, emotionally, and economically from the COVID pandemic. NEXT TUESDAY! VIRTUAL FUNDRAISER 2022 CAMPAIGN KICK-OFF EVENT RSVP: tinyurl.com/donatekelly More details below SUMMER VACCINE UPDATE Montgomery County COVID Cases & Deaths Down Dramatically This week in Montgomery County the 7-day average number of new cases is 1 per 100,000 residents. This is down dramatically from a high of 50 per 100,000 in January. For comparison, Baltimoreâ€™s case rate is 2.1 per 100,000 Prince Georgeâ€™s is 2.4 per 100,000, and D.C. has a case rate of 1.8 per 100,000 residents. Every District 16 zip code has new COVID cases in the low single digits over the last 2 week period. In May of 2021, the County, unfortunately, saw 17 COVID-related deaths. This is down from 331 deaths in May of 2020. The death rate trails the infection rate, so we should see this reduced even further. Today, there are 187 people hospitalized with COVID across Maryland. This is down from a high of 1952 people in January of 2021. Only 2% of Montgomery Countyâ€™s Intensive Care Unit beds are occupied by people with COVID. Evidence is mounting that the decrease in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths is directly related to Montgomery Countyâ€™s high vaccination rates. Delta Variant In Maryland The Delta variant of COVID, first identified in India and prominent in the UK, is spreading quickly in the US. It is present in Maryland and has grown from 3% of US COVID cases last week to 10% of cases this week. This variant is likely significantly more transmissible than the alpha variant and appears harder to treat. Studies have indicated the mRNA vaccines are highly effective against this variant, however, the second dose is essential for protection from this variant. The Johnson & Johnson vaccine has not yet been studied with this variant, but research suggests the T-cell response will be effective at preventing disease. Experts predict an increase in cases this Fall among unvaccinated individuals as a result of this variant. The more people we get fully vaccinated before the fall, the better off we will all be. Montgomery County and Maryland Vaccination Data You may have heard the great news that Montgomery County has the highest vaccination rate for people 12 and older among large counties in the United States. Montgomery County has vaccinated 65% of the population with at least one shot, slightly behind neighboring Howard County at 68%. The Maryland statewide average is 59% vaccinated (itâ€™s 72% of those 18+) with at least one shot, putting us in the top 10 in a ranking of US States, tied with New Mexico. Vaccine Rates By Social Class, Race & Gender There is a persistent correlation between vaccination rates and wealth and education level in Maryland, and across the US. Affluent and highly educated counties lead the nation in vaccination rates. Here in Maryland, there is a huge gap between the rates in Montgomery (65%) and Howard (69%) and the vaccination rates in Baltimore City (47%), Prince Georgeâ€™s County (48%), Allegheny County (41%) and Somerset County (38%). In late May, the NY Times did an in-depth analysis of this concerning trend. In Montgomery County, our vaccination rates by race and ethnicity show slight disparities in vaccination across demographic groups, with 19% of the population identifying as Black, but only 14% of vaccines going to Black residents. 20% of our population is Latino, and 17% of the vaccinated population is Latino. Statewide data shows even more significant racial and ethnic disparities. In particular, Black Marylanders are 31.1% of the population, but only 22% of the vaccinated population is Black. Among the Latino/Hispanic population, there is also a gap. Hispanics makeup 10.6% of the population, but have gotten only 7.3% of the vaccines administered. The gender gap we have seen in vaccination rates since the beginning has persisted. 53% of vaccines have gone to women and only 43% have gone to men. Ongoing Vaccination Opportunities Because of decreasing demand, most state vaccination sites are winding down operations. Greenbelt, Hagerstown, and Ripkin Stadium closed earlier in June. The Waldorf - Regency Stadium, M&T Bank Stadium, Navy-Marine Corps Stadium, and the Mall at Columbia will close over the next three weeks. The site at Six Flags will close on 7/17. However, the Montgomery County state mass vax site at Montgomery College in Germantown is an exception and will remain open for the foreseeable future. To get a vaccine through the County visit this webpage to see available (truncated)

column30: April 5, 2021 Dear Neighbor, Starting tomorrow, all Marylanders age 16 and over will be eligible for vaccines at state mass vaccination sites. Starting Monday, April 12th, all vaccine locations will be required to vaccinate anyone 16 and older. The walk-in line at the Salisbury mass vaccination site saw 500 people on Friday. Clearly, there is high demand for this ""no appointment"" option. In addition to Salisbury, starting TOMORROW, the Hagerstown mass vaccination site will accept walk-ins as well. The M&T Stadium location will open to walk-ins next week. In addition, all state mass vaccination sites (including the new Germantown location) will accept some walk-ins in the near future (dates TBD, stay tuned). Appointments are still recommended, as vaccines for walk-ins are not guaranteed. Only the Pfizer vaccine is approved for 16 and 17-year-olds. Appointments for state mass vax centers will keep this limitation in mind when offering appointments to those who are pre-registered. If you are scheduling at a pharmacy or hospital you will need to find one that utilizes Pfizer. Check this CDC website for help locating specific vaccines. Why the changes? 42% of Marylanders over age 18 are now already vaccinated. Maryland has been vaccinating more than 61,000 people a day. While it took us more than 2 months to give our first million shots, and twenty-seven days to give our second million, we have vaccinated our third million in just 19 days. Things are really speeding up. We need to vaccinate people quickly in our race against the variants. To schedule an appointment at a state mass vaccination site, call 1-855-634-6829 or pre-register at covidvax.maryland.gov. In the last week, about 500,000 people ages 16 and over have pre-registered, so it still may take a few weeks to get an appointment. For appointments at pharmacies or hospitals, use my VACCINE RESOURCE LIST. The Fascist Republican lawmakers are constantly espousing unscientific propaganda to their Stupids, who are too dumb to realize that they are more susceptible to dying, then their hated enemies the Thinking Vaccinated Citizen. On the odd chance that an Anti-Vaxxer comes upon my article, and the pictures grab their attention, I leave few bits of scientific information from Web MD. and the CDC is regards to COVID-19. HOW CONTAGIOUS IS THE CORONAVIRUS? INFO AS OF 12/18/20 The transmission rate is relatively high. Early research has estimated that one person who has it can spread it to between 2 and 3.5 others. One study found that the rate was higher, with one case spreading to between 4.7 and 6.6 other people. By comparison, one person who has the seasonal flu will pass it to between 1.1 and 2.3 others. The CDC reports there is evidence it can be transmitted if you get within 6 feet of someone who is infectious for a total of 15 minutes throughout a day. It had previously been believed the exposure had to be 15 minutes at a time. We can work to lower the transmission rate by wearing cloth face masks when we canâ€™t stay 6 feet away from others, washing handsoften, keeping common surfaces clean, limiting contact with other people, and getting vaccinated. Can a face mask protect you from infection? The CDC recommends that if you are not vaccinated, you should wear a cloth face mask if you go out in public. If you are at home with someone who has been infected or exposed, you should wear it as well. A mask is an added layer of protection for everyone, on top of social distancing efforts. You can spread the virus when you talk or cough, even if you donâ€™t know that you have it or if you arenâ€™t showing signs of infection. The CDC advises that surgical masks and N95 masks should be reserved for health care workers and first responders. HOW CAN YOU HELP STOP THE SPREAD OF THE CORONAVIRUS Because the virus spreads from person to person, itâ€™s important to limit your contact with other people as much as possible. and avoid large gatherings. Many states and cities have eased restrictions but this doesnâ€™t mean the virus is gone. Continue to follow safety practices such as wearing a cloth face mask in public places and washing your hands. GOP ABANDONS CORE IDEAS TO SCORE POINTS ON COVID On Friday, writing for The Atlantic, columnist David Graham criticized Republicans for rejecting their party's central principle of ""freedom"" to crack down on businesses that make personal decisions to impose science-based restrictions for COVID-19. One of the key governors pushing this contradiction, noted Graham, is Gov. Greg Abbott (R-TX). ""The pandemic has given Abbott new avenues to push for freedoms. Abbott has, for example, barred state agencies and organizations that receive state funding from requiring vaccines for consumers,"" wrote Graham. ""The public-health wisdom of this position is dubious, but it is consistent with the idea of limiting government restraints. What's confusing is a bill that Abbott signed in June, which bans businesses from requiring custom ers to be vaccinated. With rising concern about, and case counts from, the Delta variant, the state Alcoholic Beverage Commission issued a warning on August 12 declaring that restaurants and bars that ask customers to show proof of vaccination might have their liquor licenses revoked."" Many Republicans have of course chosen to focus on restricting local governments from imposing mandates, like Gov. Ron DeSantis (R-FL) threatening to strip pay from superintendents who impose mask mandates, and Gov. Doug Ducey (R-AZ) trying to offer incentives to schools to not require masks in a possibly unlawful scheme. But Abbott's move is something altogether different, wrote Graham. TX. column34: Jim
column35:
## Oppose  
## HB22-1201 [Standards For Immunization Requirements](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/hb22-1201)

**Hearing 3/3 at 1:30 Old State Library **before the House Business Affairs and Labor Committee 

Link for Giving Testimony to General Assembly Committees

[https://www2.leg.state.co.us/CLICS/CLICS2022A/commsumm.nsf/signup.xsp?h=SWT](https://www2.leg.state.co.us/CLICS/CLICS2022A/commsumm.nsf/signup.xsp?h=SWT)

       HB22-1201, in addition to other criteria, would allow for vaccination exemptions for anyone â€œfor any purposeâ€ simply because the vaccine has not been fully approved by the FDA or was â€œonlyâ€ approved for emergency use.  This exemption is unwarranted and over broad during  a public health emergency such as the COVID pandemic.

 An Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) requires that the FDA must determine that the known and potential benefits outweigh the known and potential risks of the vaccine and that there is adequate manufacturing information to ensure quality and consistency. The FDA made such a determination on December 11, 2020 for the use of the the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine, on December 18, 2020  for the use of the Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine, and on February 27, 2021 for the use of the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine. It was not until Aug. 23, 2021, that the FDA granted full approval to the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine, and  January 31, 2022, that the agency granted full approval for the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine. The Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine has not yet been fully approved.

 During the interim period, between the EUA and full approval of the two vaccines, hundreds of thousands of lives were saved because of them.  According to a recent study published by the Commonwealth Fund, â€œ In the absence of a vaccination program, there would have been approximately 1.1 million additional COVID-19 deaths and more than 10.3 million additional COVID-19 hospitalizations in the U.S. by November 2021.â€  https://www.commonwealthfund.org/publications/issue-briefs/2021/dec/us-covid-19-vaccination-program-one-year-how-many-deaths-and

 The exemptions proposed by HB22-1201 are without reasonable justification in light of these facts.  If the exemptions granted by this bill had been extensively given during the period from the EUA until full approval of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, many thousands more could have died and potentially hundreds of thousands more hospitalized.  Vote against this bill.
